awd_titl_txt: Gas-Phase Alloying and Sintering Kinetics of 3D Printed Ni Scaffolds
awd_abstract_narration:
The fabrication of metal parts with increasingly complex geometries is of interest to several industries. In particular, metal scaffolds are good candidates for a variety of applications from batteries to biomedical implants, due to their low density and high surface area. However, many technologically important alloys are difficult to fabricate in scaffold geometries using traditional manufacturing, and even newer approaches such as additive manufacturing (often known as 3D printing), have significant challenges. A new process has been theorized for making these metal scaffolds through a two-step approach, which will enable an assortment of different materials to be produced from the same precursor printed metal part. This award supports research to understand the fundamental mechanisms of kinetics and thermodynamics that control this new process. Because of the wide range of engineering applications for metal scaffold structures, results from this research will promote technological innovations in a number of manufacturing sectors including energy, automotive and biomedical industries. Through recruiting and outreach activities, traditionally underrepresented groups in STEM will be involved in this research effort, which will engage students at an early age and help diversify the engineering career pipeline.

While the ability to create near-net-shape metallic parts with high geometric complexity has made powder-bed additive manufacturing techniques attractive, many engineering relevant alloys are difficult to fabricate with high quality due to poor sintering, internal porosity, and cracking. One alternative approach is to decouple the printing and alloying by using particle-based ink printing to create the desired geometry from a pure metal or simple alloy that is known to print successfully, and then further alloy the part in a separate step using a deposition process and homogenization to reach the target composition. This approach is ideal for creating metallic scaffolds, taking advantage of the open porosity and small diffusion distances. The overall aim of this project is to study the fundamental sintering and alloying kinetics of such scaffolds using a combination of conventional metallography and in situ X-ray tomographic microscopy. The phase and pore evolution will be systematically studied as a function of geometry, composition, powder and strut size, and anneal time and temperature and the mechanical behavior will be computationally predicted and experimentally determined.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
With additive manufacturing, or 3D printing, recently becoming more of a reality for the production of functional metal parts, there is a need to fundamentally understand the ways in which material gets joined during the process. One of the techniques that is used in additive manufacturing is fusing metal powders together through a process called sintering. More specifically, in this project, we employed a process referred to as particle-based ink printing where a metal powder is suspended in a binder material and extruded out of a syringe. One of the goals of this project was to use traditional characterization methods along with more novel real-time imaging via X-rays to compare the sintering behavior of different materials under different conditions. Through conducting various experiments, we were able to establish that the rate at which the powders fuse together, or sinter, changes based on the powder material and initial condition it is in, but eventually the powder ends up reaching essentially the same final density regardless of these differences. In other words, when comparing non-3D printing methods with this particle-based ink extrusion technique, the result is quite similar, highlighting the feasibility of using this technique instead of what has traditionally been used that is limited in terms of geometric complexity. Another key aspect of this project was to investigate the suitability of using a process called pack cementation to control the chemical composition of lattice structures made using the 3D printing method mentioned. This is a deposition-based technique to selectively add or remove certain elements as desired to modify the properties of the material. The results of this project indicate that not only can pack cementation be used to deposit material, but it can also be used in reverse to draw out certain elements, enabling the ability to tailor the material for certain applications. With the understanding gained from this project and with further development, metal lattice structures could be fabricated from a plethora of different materials using the techniques employed for a variety of such applications from biomedical implants to energy storage devices.

Beyond the technical aspects of the project, there has been impact to students’ professional development as well. This project primarily funded one female Ph.D. student whose thesis was based on this research and who went on to become the senior testing and development scientist at an additive manufacturing company after graduating. It also partially funded two other PhD students, one who is currently a post-doctoral researcher working on metal additive manufacturing and the other is currently finishing up her degree. Additionally, this project supported three female undergraduate students at different times for research experiences, at least two of which are now planning to go to graduate school as a direct result of being involved in research early in their academic careers. The work of all of these students has also been disseminated to the scientific community through multiple technical presentations in conferences and seminars and is the foundation of four different journal articles that are being submitted. This work has enabled collaborations between our research group and other groups as well, bringing the research beyond the scope of this project to other potential applications. Using the 3D printed nickel scaffolds made in our lab as a catalyst, our collaborators synthesized 3D graphene that could be used for sensors or energy storage devices. In another collaboration, we are working with a group to develop this technique further to print materials suitable for thermoelectric devices, which are capable of converting waste heat into energy. These are just two examples of the many ways in which some of the knowledge gained and techniques utilized in this work can be extended past this particular project.


Last Modified: 05/02/2023
Modified by: Ashley Paz Y Puente
